subject: RE: [junit] J2EE "patterns"
msgSnippet: I agree with much of what you say. I would like to differentiate between J2EE and EJB s, which I think is what you are really refering to. EJB s are an as yet
messageBody:
I agree with much of what you say.

I would like to differentiate between J2EE and EJB's, which I think is what you are really refering to. EJB's are an as yet immature technology, in much the same way that JSP was when it first came out. Given a few more years and much cogitation, I'm sure that they can be fixed or replaced with something better.

I saw in a recent report on the SD conference that Scott Ambler led a panel discussion where the entire panel (including a Sun engineer) expressed disappointment with Entity EJB's.

I remember being really excited when I first heard of EJBs, but the more I try to learn about them, the more I find myself shying away from them.

Simon

>-----Original Message-----
>From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]

>
>I will make a statement that probably better belongs on
>another list, but I'll make it here and welcome either private
>responses or an invitation to a more appropriate place to discuss this.
>
>I do not react well to calling J2EE implementation idioms
>"patterns". They are hacks designed to increase performance
>and work around the obvious limitations and faulty intentions of J2EE.
>
>Session facade is not a "pattern" in the sense of "improves
>design". It is a hack that gets around the fact that J2EE
>tries to hide RMI from the programmer. If we didn't have to
>worry about remote objects, then how would we design it? I
>don't think we'd arrive at these implementation idioms/hacks
>if it weren't for working around either remote objects or a
>persistence mechanism that tries to call "save" for every method call.
>
>Comments?
>
>So said steven.hale@... on 4/4/2003 --------------------
>
>I agree with Mike here - and would even go one step further.
>Using junit
>and tdd with session ejbs encourages the 'ejb front' pattern
>(is this the
>right name?) which is a good thing.
>
>Cactus has both pros and cons.
>
>Steven Hale

>> >We wanted to build a suite of unit tests for our session beans. We
>> looked at Cactus and played with it a bit and were put off by some of
>the
>> effort involved in making it work. You have to address
>various client
>vs
>> server deployment issues, it seems confusiong wrt what code is
>executed in
>> the client vs the server ,etc.
>> >
>> >We decided not to devote that level of effort to Cactus just yet and
>> instead are writing unit tests that act as clients to the session
>beans
>> and testing them in that manner using the normal test runner.
>> >
>> >It's not clear to me what the disadvantages are to this approach.
>> Comments?
>> >
>>
>> I've found no significant disadvantages to using this approach to
>> testing remotely-accessible methods of EJB components. Then again,
>when
>> I do use EJBs it's only to "front" a non-EJB component that can be
>> tested outside of an EJB container. That is, the EJB is strictly
>> conduit. So I guess I use the approach you mention for integration
>> testing, if that distinction matters.
>>
>> IMO, Cactus is great, if you absolutely must test from within the
>> container. I strive to make those cases the exception, rather than
>the
>> rule.
